div.div: Assume that the state of the chain is now:
1. existence of PreAccountCells A, B, C;
2. there exists proposal n + 1, created at height x, which is perfectly legal;
3. there exists proposal (n + 1)', created at height y, which is perfectly legal;
Then the possible cases for a Keeper who wants to create a new proposal are:
1. x == y, and it is possible to initiate a new proposal based on any of the proposals;
2. x ! = y, which is fine if it is based on that earlier proposal;
So when a PreAccountCell is referenced by more than one proposal at the same time, it doesn't matter.

display: inline-block; font-size: 14px; font-family: JetBrains Mono; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Suppose the chain is now in the state:
There are three PreAccountCells for account A: A, A', A''.
and to solve this problem the data part of the PreAccountCell needs to contain the OutPoint of the ApplyRegisterCell.
Suppose A, A', A'' are not covered by the same proposal:
This is a simple case, after the first selected PreAccountCell passes, the others are checked for uniqueness and killed;
If A, A', A'' are covered by the same proposal.
1. the Keeper is destined to choose only one of these accounts because the contract can check for duplicates. 2;
2. then a normal Keeper should sort through the OutPoints of the ApplyRegisters in the three PreAccountCells, and select the top one;
3. If the Keeper makes an incorrect choice, there are a number of strategies available:
1. Whichever proposal passes first will take precedence. 2;
2. challenge other Keepers to reject the wrong proposal;
A PreAccountCell can be refunded to a user only if the account already exists, as monitored on the chain of AccountCells.
